alert.note: Alert for Pembina; Walsh (North Dakota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks (Northeastern North Dakota and Northwestern Minnesota)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 17 at 9:29AM CDT until April 23 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Minnesota...North Dakota... Red River of the North at East Grand Forks affecting Polk and Grand Forks Counties. ...The Flood Warning is cancelled for the following rivers in Minnesota...North Dakota... Red River of the North at Pembina affecting Kittson and Pembina Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Minnesota...North Dakota... Red River of the North at Oslo affecting Walsh, Marshall, Polk and Grand Forks Counties. Red River of the North at Drayton affecting Marshall, Kittson, Walsh and Pembina Counties. .Most of the Red River has crested and has begun to recede. Additional rises are likely due to heavy snow and ongoing snow melt, although the extent is not known at this time. Pembina is likely to experience rises over the next few days, but is not anticipated to cross flood stage over the next 2 to 3 days. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL SATURDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Red River of the North at Drayton. * WHEN...Until Saturday evening. * IMPACTS...At 32.0 feet, MINOR FLOOD. Agricultural damage begins. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 AM CDT Sunday the stage was 31.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage tomorrow evening to a crest of 32.2 feet early Tuesday afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage early Friday afternoon. - Flood stage is 32.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Safety message - Turn around, don`t drown. Don`t travel through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
